page.title: Sundance Festival of the Chamber Arts

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=July 2017}} [[File:Sundance drawing of theater.jpg|thumb|The open-air theater at Sundance]] [[File:Sundance program cover page - 1965.jpg|thumb|Program cover from 1965]] The '''Sundance Festival of the Chamber Arts''' was a cultural summer festival that took place for several years during the 1960s in [[Upper Black Eddy]] in Bucks County, Pennsylvania. It was the brainchild of the noted [[harpsichord]] builder/entrepreneur [[Wolfgang Zuckermann]]. ==History== [[File:Sundance Wolfgang Zuckermann - ca. 1963.jpg|thumb|Wolfgang Zuckermann, ca. 1963]] [[File:Sundance photo under construction spring 1963.jpg|thumb|upright=1.35|The amphitheater under construction]] [[File:Sundance map upper black eddy.jpg|thumb|Location of [[Upper Black Eddy]]]] Zuckermann's successful career as a seller of build-it-yourself harpsichord kits had been facilitated by a surge of public interest in music of the Baroque and classical periods. The festival was founded in 1963 by Zuckermann together with his colleague [[Eric Britton]] in response to this surge, as well as to rising interest in chamber music and related art forms. The two built a charming open-air [[amphitheater]], seating 250 people. The amphitheater was originally designed by Zuckermann himself and redesigned and built in partnership with local contractors. It was located on a 55 acre estate in the rural town of Upper Black Eddy, Northern Bucks County, Pennsylvania, a bit more than one hour from New York City (where Zuckermann ran his business in [[Greenwich Village]]) and rather less from Philadelphia. The rural surroundings added to the appeal of the enterprise, as [[Michael Townsend Smith]] (who succeeded Britton as director in 1966) later wrote:
It was extremely charming, and we presented a wondrous range of artists over the next three summers. Farther up the drive beyond the theatre, there were two houses, a barn, a tennis court, a big concrete swimming down in the woods, and a screened-in summer house. ... The performers often came for the weekend and enjoyed the facilities.{{Cite quote|date=February 2018}}
Zuckermann served as Managing Director, Eric Britton as Associate Director (1963-1965, followed by Smith). The festival featured chamber music, other musical artists (including, not surprisingly, various eminent harpsichordists), and some off-the-beaten path offering such as marionette opera. The festival took place in the months of July and August. There were two performances weekly, Friday and Saturday nights, solely dedicated to chamber music, modern dance, drama, poetry readings, and film. Admission was $2.00 per concert. The chamber music events were entirely devoted to classical music and featured some of the most appreciated groups of the time (Galimir String Quartet, the Kroll Quartet, the Claremont Quartet, Krainis Baroque Trio), harpsichordists (including Fernando Valenti, Sylvia Marlowe, Pamela Cook, Robert Conant), and distinguished musicians and singers (Helen Boatwright, Sanford Allen, Peter Serkin, Michael Tree, Rey de la Torre, Daniel Weisman, Suzanne Bloch among them). An edge to the festival was given by less familiar, at times more experiment works, such as the dance presentations of the James Waring Company, Merce Cunningham (and John Cage), and Yvonne Rainer, among them. Sundance also presented off-off Broadway plays, marionette operas, poetry readings Allen Ginsburg and low budget films of what was then called the Independent American Cinema.
The last performances at Sundance took place in Summer 1968. In 1969, Zuckermann moved to England, selling both his harpsichord business as well as the Sundance property, and the Sundance Festival came to an end. ==Reception== One enthusiastic patron wrote at the time: "Sundance is the newest and brightest star in the Bucks County firmament. The setting is a charming sylvan one, deep in a wooded area. The comfortable seating is, in true theater fashion so that one has an obstructed view from every point. The stage is handsome having a proscenium on which the names of the geniuses of the past and present are carved in gold on a dark brown with background. But the most interesting aspect before one enters the open air seating area and views the stage is that of the Mexican Indian like stucco wall, which forms the background of the theater, and seems to convey the idea of an abstract painting. And there is peace and beauty here – and excitement."The quotation is taken from the back cover of [[:File:Sundance program back cover - 1965.jpg|a program]] for one of the Sundance performances. ==Programming== ===1963=== [[File:Sundance dance rehearsel summer 1963.jpg|thumb|A dance rehearsal from 1963]] {{expand list|date=February 2017}} * [[Yvonne Rainer]] * [[Sylvia Marlowe]] * Frank Paris Marionette Opera. [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]'s ''[[Bastien und Bastienne]]''. [[Joseph Haydn]]'s ''Philemon und Baucis''. * [[Felix Galimir|Galimir]] String Quartet ?? * Kroll String Quartet ?? * New American Cinema ?? * [[Fernando Valenti]] * Tina Brown * [[Judson Dance Theater]] * Claremont Quartet * Pamela Cook * Robert Conant * [[Helen Boatwright]] * Sanford Allen * Daniel Weisman * [[Suzanne Bloch]] ===1964 === {{expand list|date=February 2017}} * [[Peter Serkin]] and [[Michael Tree]] * [[Lucinda Childs]] * Judson Dance Theater * Kroll String Quartet ? * Gallimard Quartet * New American Cinema ?? ===1965=== [[File:Sundance program 1 - 1965.jpg|thumb|Sundance program from 1965]] [[File:Sundance program 2 - 1965.jpg|thumb|Sundance program from 1965]] * The Brass Arts Quartet * [[Rey de la Torre]], Classical guitar * [[Curtis String Quartet]]. * [[Albert Fuller]], harpsichord. * Robert Koff, violin, and Louis Bagger, harpsichord. * [[Joseph Marx]] Baroque Ensemble. * [[John Cage]], piano. [[David Tudor]], piano * [[Merce Cunningham]] and Dance Company ===1966=== [[File:Sundance program cover page - 1966.jpg|thumb|Program cover from 1966]] * Judson Chamber Ensemble.(2 concerts) * Beverly Smith/Roberts Blossoms – Filmstages * [[The Open Theater]] – "Viet rock" * The [[Festival Winds]] * Judson Poets Theater * [[Claremont String Quartet]] (3 concerts) * New American Cinema. * [[La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club|La MaMa]] Repertory. – ''Chicago'' * [[Allen Ginsberg]]/[[Peter Ganesh Orlovsky]] – Poems * New York Chamber Soloists. * [[Katherine Litz]] and Aileen Passloff/Remy Charlip * [[Paul Jacobs (pianist)|Paul Jacobs]], harpsichord. * Al Carmines – theater songs * [[Joseph Marx Baroque Ensemble]] * [[La Monte Young]] – Experiments * [[Cecil Taylor Trio]] * Manhattan Festival Ballet For additional information:{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/Sundance-Festival-of-the-Chamber-Arts-604323356443969/|title=Sundance Festival of the Chamber Arts|website=Facebook.com|accessdate=29 July 2017}} ===1967=== * July 19: Fernando Valenti, harpsichord, in a recital of Spanish Baroque music including works by Scarlatti and Soler * July 20: Robert Schwartz: X-ing, a multiform dance work—assemblages, moments, improvisations—performed by the choreographer with Delila Zuck and others * July 26: Opera Bluestocking: "In a Garden", by Meyer Kupferman and Gertrude Stein; "The Secular Mask" by William Boyce; and "The Fortress of Ares" by Bela Bartok * July 27: Princeton String Quartet: Haydn's "Seven Last Words of Christ", in mourning for all the victims of the war in Vietnam * August 2: James Oliver Buswell IV, violin, and Fernando Valenti, harpsichord, in a program of sonatas by Bach * August 3: "The Hawk", by Murray Mednick and Tony Barsha, a radical experiment in improvisational ritual theatre, with the original off-off-Broadway cast * August 4: Student recital: works for one, two, and three harpsichords, performance by advanced students of Fernando Valenti's Sundance master classes * August 9: New York Chamber Soloists: piano quartets and piano trios by Haydn, Mozart, and Schumann * August 10: New York Chamber Soloists: all-contemporary program including the Harpsichord Concerto by Manuel de Falla and the Sonata for Flute, Oboe, Cello, and Harpsichord by Elliott Carter * August 16: The Gift Rite: Ken Dewey Action Theatre in a jazz/medieval collision with the myth of fire—a happening * August 17–18: New American Cinema * August 25–56: "POPPY NOGOOD" by [[Terry Riley]], "Medicine Dance" by [[Trisha Brown]], "Shirt" by R. Whitman ==Commentaries== From [[Michael Townsend Smith]]: {{block indent|left=1.5|1=Zuckermann had done three summer seasons at Sundance with an English friend [[Eric Britton]] who had now moved to Paris. Deep in the woods in northern [[Bucks County, Pennsylvania]], two hours west of New York, they had built a small covered stage and a wide amphitheatre for the audience that was open to the stars. It was extremely charming, and we presented a wondrous range of artists over the next three summers. Farther up the drive beyond the theatre, there were two houses, a barn, a tennis court, a big concrete swimming down in the woods, and a screened-in summer house. Wolfgang and I got to be good friends, playing chamber music together in the city and tennis at Sundance. The performers often came for the weekend and enjoyed the facilities. For our third season the great Catalan harpsichord [[Fernando Valenti]] was in residence, and Wolfgang fixed up the horse stalls as practice rooms for his students. But the following year, appalled by America's political power, Wolfgang sold Sundance and moved abroad. He presently owns and operates Librairie Shakespeare, a bookshop in Avignon.{{cite web|url=http://www.michaeltownsendsmith.com/sundance|title=Michael Townsend Smith: Sundance|website=Michaeltownsendsmith.com|accessdate=29 July 2017}}}} From [[Eric Britton]], Paris: {{block indent|left=1.5|1=Years later (February 2018) I have come to regret that Wolfgang and I designed Sundance and the program in light of our own particular tastes and preferences (one might say a bit elitist). In retrospect I rather wish that we had spread our wings a bit and welcomed other less erudite performing arts forms to help us engage a wider audience and permanence.

Despite our extending the focus from our original point of departure (chamber music and that's it!) to house and welcome performances of modern dance, Off-Broadway plays and what we then called The New American Cinema (low cost experimental and student productions), I have come to think in retrospect that we should have stretched further: different shades of jazz, audience singing, and poetry slams. Perhaps the next time around?{{Cite quote|date=February 2018}}}} ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== *"Sundance arts fete to open in Bucks County, July 26". ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 3, 1963. [[Category:Chamber music festivals]] [[Category:Classical music festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Dance festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Theatre festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Film festivals in Pennsylvania]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}} {{About||the song by Maps & Atlases|Super Bowl Sunday (song)|the episode of ''This Is Us''|Super Bowl Sunday (This Is Us)}} {{Infobox holiday | holiday_name = Super Sunday | type = cultural | image = File:Super Bowl Sunday Military.jpg | imagesize = 300px | caption = [[United States Air Force]] Super Bowl Party. | official_name = Super Sunday | nickname = Super Bowl Sunday | observedby = [[United States]], [[Canada]], and internationally | litcolor = | longtype = | significance = | begins = 1967 | duration = 1 day | frequency = annual | scheduling = <!-- Use next three if holiday is the same day of the same week every year --> | week_ordinal = first | weekday = Sunday | month = February <!-- Use next three if the date changes in an unusual pattern each year --> | date2016 = February 7 | date2017 = February 5 | celebrations = | observances = | relatedto = }} '''Super Bowl Sunday''' is the day on which the [[Super Bowl]], the [[National Football League]] (NFL)'s annual championship game, is played. It is usually observed on the first Sunday in February and is sometimes referred to as an unofficial national holiday. The 52nd annual event, [[Super Bowl LII]], occurred on February 4, 2018. Festivities for Super Sunday typically involve groups of people gathering to watch the game. Both "Super Sunday" and "Super Bowl Sunday" are registered [[trademark]]s of the National Football League.<ref>[http://www.ipbrief.net/2014/01/27/the-super-trademark-bowl/ The Super – Trademark – Bowl]. [[American University]]</ref>
==Festivities== Although not an [[Public holidays in the United States|official holiday]], Super Sunday is an occasion when many families and friends gather together to watch the game, including those who are not normally football fans.<ref name=tftu>{{cite news|last=Stellino|first=Vito|title=Super Sunday feels like a holiday|url=http://jacksonville.com/sports/football/jaguars/2010-02-06/story/super_bowl_sunday_feels_like_a_holiday|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=The Florida Times Union|date=February 6, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Gay|first=Jason|title=Should the Super Bowl Be a Holiday?|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/should-the-super-bowl-be-a-holiday-1454612826?tesla=y|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=February 4, 2016|accessdate=November 13, 2016}}</ref> Although [[sports bar]]s have historically been busy on Super Sunday in the past, it is becoming more common for people to watch the game from home. This is due in part to the increasing size of home televisions in the United States as well as the attempts of budget conscious consumers to save money.<ref name=twsj02>{{cite news|last=Jargon|first=Julie|title=Sports Bars Play Super Bowl Defense|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704680604576110050697188540|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=February 3, 2011}}</ref><ref name=twsj01>{{cite news|last=Halls|first=Sarah|title=Where to Watch the Super Bowl in Europe|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704709304576124013128512114|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=February 5, 2011}}</ref>
Because watching the Super Bowl is so popular, stores are often empty during the game, particularly in the regions represented by the two teams playing in the Super Bowl,<ref name=tn>{{cite news|last=Bollier|first=Jeff|title=Oshkosh shuts down for Packers, Super Bowl|url=http://www.thenorthwestern.com/article/20110206/OSH0101/102060328/Oshkosh-shuts-down-for-Super-Bowl|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=The Northwestern|date=February 6, 2011|location=Oshkosh, Wisconsin}}</ref> and water usage drops, with significant rises in use during halftime and after the game, as fans use the bathroom.<ref name="calder20120209">{{cite news|last=Calder|first=Rich|title=Toilet Bowl XLVI|url=https://nypost.com/2012/02/09/toilet-bowl-xlvi/|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|date=February 9, 2012|accessdate=February 1, 2018}}</ref> Additionally, churches sometimes cancel afternoon or evening services on Super Sunday, hold football-themed charity drives, or deliver sermons designed to appeal to male members of the congregation.<ref name=tva>{{cite news|title=Some churches cancel Super Sunday services|url=http://www.victoriaadvocate.com/news/2011/feb/03/bc-wi-super-bowl-sunday-services/?sports&nfl|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=The Victoria Advocate|date=February 3, 2011|agency=Associated Press|location=Victoria, Texas}}</ref><ref name=dp>{{cite news|last=Draper|first=Electa|title=Some preachers use Super Bowl to put focus on harm of pornography|url=http://www.denverpost.com/ci_17299496|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=Dever Post|date=February 5, 2011}}</ref><ref name=hs>{{cite news|last=Kloosterman|first=Stephen|title=Churches see Super Bowl as a time to connect with worshippers|url=http://www.hollandsentinel.com/newsnow/x549731920/Churches-see-Super-Bowl-as-a-time-to-connect-with-worshippers|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=Holland Sentinel|date=February 6, 2011|location=Holland, Michigan}}</ref>
NFL executives have called for a three-day weekend in order to allow fans to celebrate the event, and there is thought to be a loss of [[productivity]] in the American work force on Monday after the event.<ref name=LAT/><ref>{{cite news|last=Riccobono|first=Anthony|title=Should The Monday After The Super Bowl Be A National Holiday?|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/should-monday-after-super-bowl-be-national-holiday-1798312|website=[[International Business Times]]|date=February 1, 2015|accessdate=November 13, 2016}}</ref> The television network carrying the game (either [[NFL on CBS|CBS]], [[Fox NFL|Fox]], or [[NBC Sunday Night Football|NBC]]) will usually devote the entire day's programming schedule to the game, with extended pregame shows, [[NFL Films]] retrospectives of the previous season, and special versions of the [[Sunday morning talk show]]s in the morning and afternoon hours leading into the game. Competing networks, due to the severe loss of viewers to the Super Bowl festivities, generally resort to low-cost [[Super Bowl counterprogramming|counterprogramming]] measures like the ''[[Puppy Bowl]].''<ref>{{cite news|last=Ryzik|first=Melena|title=Just Fine as Tackles, but They Can’t Pass|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/02/arts/television/02bark.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 2, 2008|accessdate=February 1, 2018}}</ref>
==Food== Large amounts of food and alcohol are consumed on Super Sunday.<ref name=LAT>{{cite news|last=Flint|first=Joe|title=NFL has made Super Bowl Sunday into a holiday, is a three-day weekend the next step?|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2011/02/nfl-has-made-super-bowl-sunday-into-a-holiday-is-a-three-day-weekend-the-next-step.html|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=February 4, 2011}}</ref><ref name=si>{{cite news|last=Deford|first=Frank|title=Super Bowl Sunday is a holiday|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/writers/frank_deford/01/28/SuperBowl/|accessdate=February 6, 2011|date=January 28, 2009|work=CNN}}</ref><ref name=wgn>{{cite news|last=Zellermayer|first=J|title=Super Bowl Sunday drunk driving crackdown|url=http://www.wgntv.com/wgntv-drunk-driving-crackdown-super-feb6,0,3426624.story|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[WGN-TV]]|date=February 6, 2011|accessdate=February 6, 2011}}</ref> The event is the second-largest food consumption event in the United States, behind only [[Thanksgiving dinner]],<ref name=tac/> and some police departments have noticed a dramatic increase in [[drunk driving]] on Super Sunday.<ref name="wgn"/>
Super Sunday food is usually served [[buffet]] style, rather than as a sit-down meal. Foods traditionally eaten on Super Sunday include [[buffalo wing]]s, [[Chili con carne|chili]], [[pork ribs|baby back ribs]], [[Dip (food)|dipping sauces]], [[pizza]], and [[potato chip]]s.<ref name=tac>{{cite news|last=Corwin|first=Tom|title=Super Bowl party food need not send diets crashing|url=http://chronicle.augusta.com/news/metro/2011-02-05/super-bowl-party-food-need-not-send-diets-crashing|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=The Augusta Chronicle|date=February 5, 2011|location=Augusta, Georgia}}</ref><ref name=ttl/> Many [[pizza delivery]] businesses see their order numbers double as roughly 60 percent of the take out ordered on Super Sunday is pizza. Roughly {{convert|28000000|lb|kg}} of chips, 1.25 billion chicken wings, and {{convert|8000000|lb|kg}} of [[guacamole]] are consumed during Super Sunday.<ref name=ttl>{{cite news|last=Lynott|first=Jerry|title=Score super snacks|url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/Score_super_snacks_01-31-2011.html|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=The Times Leader|date=February 1, 2011|location=Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania}}</ref><ref name=wpde>{{cite news|last=Edge|first=Lisa|title=Super Sunday means big business for food industry|url=http://www.carolinalive.com/news/story.aspx?id=577049|accessdate=February 6, 2011|newspaper=WPDE|date=February 4, 2011}}</ref>

{{Neologism|date=May 2011}} {{Primary sources|date=August 2008}} A '''Tech tabloid''' is a type of news media that mainly concentrates on technology news: science, IT, semiconductors, telecoms and related issues, but also takes on a less formal and more humorous approach than traditional technology publications such as [[EE Times]] or [[EDN (magazine)|EDN]]. They are professional in nature, though, rather than community-based technology news sites such as [[Digg]] or [[Slashdot]].
==Tabloid nature==
[[Tabloid journalism|Tabloid]] newspapers traditionally aim for sensationalist stories, celebrity news and aim for a down-market reader. The tabloid tag does not apply to the paper format, as many of these publications are web-based only, such as [[The Inquirer]] and [[The Register]].
The sarcastic, iconoclastic and skeptic tones of these publications is often more akin to publication such as [[Private Eye]], which would not usually be labelled a tabloid, than to the [[Page Three]] tabloid such as ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' and the ''[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]''.
The Inquirer even, in its 20000th article, refers to itself as "redtop tabloid rags like the INQUIRER",<ref>[http://www.theinquirer.net/default.aspx?article=20000 The Inquirer's 20000th article] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060830181356/http://www.theinquirer.net/default.aspx?article=20000 |date=30 August 2006 }} (cited 20 December 2006)</ref> later in the same article calling itself "cheesy": determining the irony of this is left as an exercise to the reader. Both the Register and the Inquirer do generally have red banners at the top of their home pages.

{{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = The Case for Impeachment | image = The Case for Impeachment.jpg | alt = Book cover | caption = Book cover | author = [[Allan Lichtman]] | audio_read_by = | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[Politics of the United States]] | genre = Non-fiction | publisher = [[Dey Street Books]] | publisher2 = [[William Collins (publisher)|William Collins]] | pub_date = April 18, 2017 | media_type = Hardcover | pages = 304 | isbn = 978-0-06-269682-3 | oclc = 988564615 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = [[The Keys to the White House]] (1996) | notes =<ref name=thankyou /><ref name=lozada /><ref name=smilke /> | website ={{official website|https://www.thecaseforimpeachment.com/}} }} '''''The Case for Impeachment''''' is a non-fiction book by [[American University]] Distinguished Professor of History [[Allan Lichtman]] arguing for the [[Efforts to impeach Donald Trump|impeachment of Donald Trump]]. It was published on April 18, 2017 by [[Dey Street Books]], an imprint of [[HarperCollins]]. Lichtman predicted to ''[[The Washington Post]]'' that after ascending to the presidency, Trump would later be impeached from office. He developed this thesis into a set of multiple arguments for Trump's predicted impeachment.<ref name="Trump headed" /><ref name=lozada />
Lichtman argues in the book that Trump could face impeachment for reasons including: complicity of conspiracy with foreign governments, [[crimes against humanity]] for the U.S. neglecting [[global warming]], and violation of the [[Foreign Emoluments Clause]] of the constitution barring the president from taking personal monetary offerings from other governments. He provides the reader with an overview of [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] and [[links between Trump associates and Russian officials]], asserting such ties could be used in [[efforts to impeach Donald Trump|efforts to impeach President Trump]]. He uses the [[Watergate scandal]] as the backdrop to compare Trump's reactions to criticism with those of [[Richard Nixon]] during [[Impeachment of Richard Nixon|Nixon's impeachment process]]. The author discusses [[Donald Trump sexual misconduct allegations|assertions of sexual misconduct against Trump]], and delves into some of the [[legal affairs of Donald Trump|his legal affairs]] stemming from them. Lichtman places the [[Donald Trump and Billy Bush recording]]s within a larger context of public degradation of women.<ref name=thankyou /><ref name=lozada /><ref name=smilke />
The ''[[Financial Times]]'' gave ''The Case for Impeachment'' a positive review, writing: "Lichtman's powerful book is a reminder that we are only at the start of the Trump investigations."<ref name=thankyou /> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' called it "striking to see the full argument unfold".<ref name=lozada /> ''New York Journal of Books'' recommended it as a resource, "if you are a member of Congress trying to grapple with all that this administration has wrought".<ref name=smilke /> ''[[CounterPunch]]'' characterized the work as "a brilliant analysis of every fraudulent act".<ref name=larson /> ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' gave the author praise, writing: "Lichtman has written what may be the most important book of the year."<ref name=budowsky /> [[CBC News]] consulted law scholars who said Lichtman's impeachment prediction was unlikely, especially with a Republican-controlled [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]].<ref name=cbcnews />
==Contents summary== {{see|Efforts to impeach Donald Trump}}
''The Case for Impeachment'' sets forth multiple arguments why President Trump's actions warrant impeachment from office. The author organizes the book into subsets of different grounds for impeachment. These include complicity or conspiracy with foreign governments. Lichtman explains to the reader the [[Foreign Emoluments Clause]] of the constitution, barring the president from taking personal monetary offerings from other governments. The author contends impeachment could be brought for actions by the president intended to benefit himself financially based on [[insider trading|inside information]] about economic dealings. Lichtman observes the president has not garnered knowledge from a study of earlier key events in U.S. politics: "A president who seems to have learned nothing from history is abusing and violating the public trust and setting the stage for a myriad of impeachable offenses."<ref name=thankyou /><ref name=lozada /><ref name=smilke />
Lichtman compares and contrasts Trump's actions with the [[Impeachment of Richard Nixon]] stemming from the [[Watergate scandal]]. Discussion of prior impeachment proceedings for presidents [[Andrew Johnson]] and [[Bill Clinton]] are placed within historical context, and the book makes comparisons between Trump and [[Richard Nixon]].<ref name=tomwarren> {{citation|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=els1k6qifGU|first=Tom|last=Warren|work=[[Politics and Prose]]|title=Allan J Lichtman, 'The Case For Impeachment'|date=May 10, 2017|type=video}}</ref> The author writes that Trump's decisions threaten American values: "Even early in his presidency, Donald Trump exhibits the same tendencies that led Nixon to violate the most basic standards of morality and threaten the foundations of our democracy."<ref name=lozada /> Lichtman argues that Trump's failure to learn from Nixon's negative example will harm his presidency, noting: "They also shared a compulsion to deflect blame, and they were riddled with insecurities." He criticizes what he documents as Trump's disregard for veracity: "Neither man allowed the law, the truth, the free press, or the potential for collateral damage to others to impede their personal agendas."<ref name=lozada /> Lichtman feels Trump and Nixon's potential political success can be viewed as stifled by a perceived need for covert decision making devoid of critical viewpoints: "They obsessed over secrecy and thirsted for control without dissent."<ref name=thankyou /><ref name=lozada /><ref name=smilke />
The author provides an overview of actions taken by Trump before his presidency that could also lead to his downfall, including possible violations of the [[Fair Housing Act]], the operations of [[Trump University]], and donations or lack thereof related to the [[Donald J. Trump Foundation]]. With regard to the Foreign Emoluments Clause, the author outlines for the reader the basis for impeachment with discussion of Trump and Trump family debt, trademark negotiations with China, and financial transactions in the Philippines, arguing these obligations could allow foreign powers control over the Trump Administration.<ref name=lozada /> In a proposal that the author acknowledges is unlikely, he submits the [[International Criminal Court]] could potentially prosecute the president for [[crimes against humanity]] related to reneging on agreements to combat [[climate change]]. Legally this would not have significant standing on its own for impeachment in the U.S. however, the author suggests that it could provide the moral impetus for legislators to take further actions instead.<ref name=thankyou /><ref name=lozada /><ref name=smilke />
''The Case for Impeachment'' devotes a chapter to [[Donald Trump sexual misconduct allegations|assertions of sexual misconduct made by women against Trump]], and details some of [[legal affairs of Donald Trump|Trump's legal affairs]] stemming from them. Lichtman describes Trump as driven by lust, and places the [[Donald Trump and Billy Bush recording]] within a larger context of public degradation of women. Events contained in the discussion of this topic are later contrasted with the fact that despite such details, Trump garnered a majority of white female voters' support compared to his opponent [[Hillary Clinton]].<ref name=thankyou /><ref name=lozada /><ref name=smilke />
Lichtman takes the reader through [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] and links between Trump associates and Russian officials, and writes that President Trump: "stands a chance of becoming the first American president charged with treason or the failure to report treason by agents and associates".<ref name=lozada /> He likens the multiple investigations by the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]], the [[House Intelligence Committee]], and the [[Senate Intelligence Committee]] into Russian interference in the 2016 U.S. election, and Trump associates' links a "[[Sword of Damocles]]" awaiting Trump. The author concludes these investigations could have disastrous impact for the president: "Neither Republicans nor Democrats in Congress will tolerate a compromised or treacherous president. Impeachment and trial will be quick and decisive."<ref name=thankyou /><ref name=lozada /><ref name=smilke />

On November 11, 2016, three days after Trump won the 2016 US presidential election, Lichtman reiterated to ''The Washington Post'' another prediction he had made in September 2016 – that Trump would be impeached as president.<ref name=predictionprofessor>{{citation|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/11/11/prediction-professor-who-called-trumps-big-win-also-made-another-forecast-trump-will-be-impeached |work=[[The Washington Post]] |access-date=June 5, 2017 |title='Prediction professor' who called Trump's big win also made another forecast: Trump will be impeached |date=November 11, 2016 |first=Peter W. |last=Stevenson |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170608074929/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/11/11/prediction-professor-who-called-trumps-big-win-also-made-another-forecast-trump-will-be-impeached/ |archivedate=June 8, 2017 }}</ref><ref name=tafrank>{{citation|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |access-date=June 5, 2017 |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/11/will-trump-be-impeached |title=Will Trump be impeached? |first=T.A. |last=Frank |date=November 14, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170321070009/http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/11/will-trump-be-impeached |archivedate=March 21, 2017 }}</ref> He predicted this reasoning that a Republican controlled US Congress would rather have a more stable [[Mike Pence]] elevated from [[Vice President of the United States]] to the presidency.<ref name=predictionprofessor /> He explained to ''The Washington Post'': "They don't want Trump as president, because they can't control him. He's unpredictable. They'd love to have Pence – an absolutely down-the-line, conservative, controllable Republican."<ref name=predictionprofessor /> Lichtman elaborated on the likelihood of his impeachment assessment: "I'm quite certain Trump will give someone grounds for impeachment, either by doing something that endangers national security or because it helps his pocketbook."<ref name=predictionprofessor /> interview with Lichtman conducted by Steve Scully on ''The Case for Impeachment'', May 14, 2017], [[C-SPAN]]}} Lichtman was engaged in writing the book in February 2017.<ref name=writingprocess /><ref>{{citation|access-date=June 5, 2017 |work=[[The Independent]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/professor-allan-lichtman-donald-trump-impeached-us-presidential-election-prediction-1984-american-a7593826.html |title=Professor who |archivedate=May 22, 2017 }}</ref> His representative from [[HarperCollins]] publishers told ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine that Lichtman's thesis focused on: "not a question of ''if'' President Trump will be impeached, but a question of ''when''".<ref name=writingprocess>{{citation|access-date=June 5, 2017 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |title=That Professor Who Predicted Donald |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170604140230/http://time.com/4677042/donald-trump-impeachment-book/ |archivedate=June 4, 2017 }}</ref> During the writing process, Lichtman focused his efforts on outlining a thesis explaining why Trump was vulnerable to being removed from office, due to concerns about [[links between Trump associates and Russian officials]], and possible conflicts of interest tied to his global financial dealings.<ref name=writingprocess /> Whereas his September 2016 prediction of a Trump win in the US presidential election was based on a tested prediction model, his basis for the impeachment thesis was more of a qualitative analysis.<ref name=lozada /> Lichtman explained to [[Steve Scully]] of [[C-SPAN]] his reason for writing the book, "I wrote it as a deep historical analysis for the history of the impeachment process prior to the presidency. I wrote it so people could arm themselves with the knowledge of when Trump might have crossed the line to begin impeachment."<ref name=stevescully>{{citation|agency=[[C-SPAN]] |date=May 14, 2017 |title=Allan Lichtman on Possible Impeachment Proceedings Against President Trump |url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?428430-4/washington-journal-allan-lichtman-discusses-possible-impeachment-proceedings-president-trump |work=[[Washington Journal]] |first=Steve |last=Scully |authorlink=Steve Scully |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170620073055/https://www.c-span.org/video/?428430-4%2Fwashington-journal-allan-lichtman-discusses-possible-impeachment-proceedings-president-trump |archivedate=June 20, 2017 }}</ref>
In an interview with ''[[GQ (magazine)|GQ]]'' magazine, Lichtman explained his thought process for predicting a Trump impeachment: "it is based on a deep study of history, including Trump's parallels to his impeached predecessors; a study of the process of impeachment; a study of Trump's vulnerabilities".<ref name=willis /> He explained why he chose to write the book at this particular point, emphasizing it was to provide a guide for the public, and "because impeachment is a political process that occurs outside of the courts. It is responsive to the people, and if impeachment is going to take place, it will be because the American people demand it."<ref name=willis /> Lichtman said because there were many potential unlawful activities, "I believe he is more vulnerable than any early president in the history of the nation."<ref name=willis />
==Release and reception== Prior to finishing the book, Lichtman had a contract with [[Dey Street Books]] to publish it in the US with a publication date of April 18, 2017.<ref name=writingprocess /> On March 3, 2017, the publisher [[William Collins (publisher)|William Collins]] bought the rights to publish and sell the book in the UK and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] excluding Canada also for release in April.<ref name=natasha>{{citation|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/william-collins-buys-book-case-trumps-impeachment-499956|access-date=June 5, 2017|work=[[The Bookseller]]|title=The case for Donald Trump's impeachment bought by William Collins|date=March 3, 2017|first=Natasha|last=Onwuemezi}}</ref> The contract was reported as being a "significant deal".<ref name=natasha /> ''The Case for Impeachment'' was first published in hardcover format on April 18, 2017, in the US.<ref>{{citation|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |first=Katie |last=Reilly |access-date=June 5, 2017 |url=http://time.com/4740923/allan-lichtman-case-for-impeachment-donald-trump/ |title=How the Professor Who Predicted Trump's Win is Making the Case for Impeachment |date=April 14, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170604140222/http://time.com/4740923/allan-lichtman-case-for-impeachment-donald-trump/ |archivedate=June 4, 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{oclc|988564615}}</ref> It was also released in [[e-book]] and [[audiobook]] formats.<ref>{{oclc|988217468}}</ref><ref>{{oclc|985008578}}</ref> The UK Commonwealth edition was published in [[London]].<ref>{{oclc|985462475}}</ref> Within the first seven weeks after the book was first published, 10,000 copies were purchased for sale.<ref>{{citation|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/143599/ultimate-salesman-how-trump-helps-revive-publishing|work=[[The New Republic]]|access-date=July 26, 2017|title=Ultimate Salesman|first=Alex|last=Shephard|date=July 20, 2017}}</ref>
''[[The Washington Post]]'' journalist Carlos Lozada wrote in a review that on reading the book, it was "striking to see the full argument unfold and realize that you don't have to be a zealot to imagine some version of it happening".<ref name=lozada /> He concluded: "Lichtman's case for impeachment is plausible, certainly, but it is far stronger as an argument for why Americans never should have elected Trump in the first place. Yet we did. So it may not be too soon for this book, after all. It may be too late."<ref name=lozada /> Joy Lo Dico reviewed the book for the ''[[London Evening Standard]]'' writing: "His argument races through 200 pages, with steam for more."<ref name=standard>{{citation|work=[[London Evening Standard]] |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/books/the-case-for-impeachment-by-allan-j-lichtman-review-a3519186.html |title=The Case for Impeachment by Allan J Lichtman – review |access-date=June 5, 2017 |first=Joy Lo |last=Dico |date=April 20, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170709005043/http://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/books/the-case-for-impeachment-by-allan-j-lichtman-review-a3519186.html |archivedate=July 9, 2017 }}</ref> ''New York Journal of Books'' contributor Basil Smilke Jr. reviewed the book favorably, writing: "''The Case for Impeachment'' is a good backdrop for conversations that will likely remain a part of our national dialogue for some time – or if you are a member of Congress trying to grapple with all that this administration has wrought."<ref name=smilke>{{citation|first=Basil|last=Smilke Jr.|work=New York Journal of Books|url=http://www.nyjournalofbooks.com/book-review/case-impeachment|title=The Case for Impeachment|date=April 17, 2017|access-date=June 5, 2017}}</ref> ''[[AM Joy]]'' host [[Joy-Ann Reid]] said it was a "fascinating book," particularly because Lichtman had been one of the only prognosticators to correctly predict Trump would win the 2016 election.<ref name=joyannreid /> [[Joe Scarborough]] on ''[[Morning Joe]]'' called the book "liberal catnip".<ref name=scarborough />
Writing for the ''[[Financial Times]]'', Edward Luce gave the book a positive review, concluding: "Lichtman's powerful book is a reminder that we are only at the start of the Trump investigations. The US system takes a long time to gather speed. Once it does, it can be hard to stop."<ref name=thankyou>{{citation|url=https://www.ft.com/content/f9247b54-242d-11e7-8691-d5f7e0cd0a16 |title=The case for impeaching Donald Trump |access-date=June 5, 2017 |date=April 20, 2017 |first=Edward |last=Luce |work=[[Financial Times]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170604070212/https://www.ft.com/content/f9247b54-242d-11e7-8691-d5f7e0cd0a16 |archivedate=June 4, 2017 }}</ref> In a review for ''[[CounterPunch]]'', Charles R. Larson wrote: "What is so compelling about ''The Case for Impeachment'' is the plethora of acts by Donald Trump that in a sane world would have brought him down long before he even ran for president."<ref name=larson>{{citation|title=Review: Allan Lichtman's 'The Case for Impeachment' |date=May 19, 2017 |access-date=June 5, 2017 |first=Charles R. |last=Larson |url=https://www.counterpunch.org/2017/05/19/review-allan-lichtmans-the-case-for-impeachment/ |work=[[CounterPunch]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170612155529/https://www.counterpunch.org/2017/05/19/review-allan-lichtmans-the-case-for-impeachment/ |archivedate=June 12, 2017 }}</ref> Larson recommended the book to potential readers: "you need to read ''The Case for Impeachment'', a brilliant analysis of every fraudulent act committed by the child in the White House".<ref name=larson /> Brent Budowsky reviewed the book for ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'' and praised it, writing: "Lichtman has written what may be the most important book of the year."<ref name=budowsky>{{citation|first=Brent|last=Budowsky|work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|access-date=June 5, 2017|url=http://origin-nyi.thehill.com/blogs/pundits-blog/the-administration/329654-its-time-to-seriously-explore-trumps-financial-ties|title=How far is too far? The Trump impeachment debate begins now.|date=April 20, 2017}}</ref> He agreed with the premise that the book should start a wider debate in the public: "I am suggesting that Professor Lichtman is right: America should now begin a serious debate about how far is too for the leader of the land of the free and the home of the brave."<ref name=budowsky />
[[CBC News]] interviewed academics including constitutional law expert and resource for the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|U.S. House Judiciary Committee]] in the [[impeachment of Bill Clinton]], Susan Low Bloch, who were skeptical of some of the book's arguments.<ref name=cbcnews>{{citation|access-date=June 5, 2017 |work=[[CBC News]] |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/allan-lichtman-prediction-prof-trump-impeachment-1.4073261 |title=Analysis – 'Prediction prof' who called Trump's win now predicts his impeachment, but scholars aren't convinced |date=April 18, 2017 |first=Matt |last=Kwong |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170614173551/http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/allan-lichtman-prediction-prof-trump-impeachment-1.4073261 |archivedate=June 14, 2017 }}</ref> Bloch opined that impeachment was not as easy as was thought: "You are undoing a national election, and I can't think of anything more serious politically than undoing an election. Whether you like Trump or not, he's now the president until he's done something impeachable – which he hasn't, so far as we know."<ref name=cbcnews />

{{italic title}} '''''The Danton Case''''' is a 1929 historical [[Play (theatre)|play]] by the Polish writer [[Stanisława Przybyszewska]]. The work portrays the conflict between the rival revolutionaries [[Maximilien Robespierre]] and [[Georges Danton]] during the [[French Revolution]], particularly in the period leading up to Danton's execution. Przybyszewska wrote the play between March 1928 and March 1929, after many years of studying the French Revolution.
==Adaptations== The 1932 French film ''[[Danton (1932 film)|Danton]]'' and the 1983 Polish-French film ''[[Danton (1983 film)|Danton]]'' both drew inspiration from the play.

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} [[Image:UNDIE500 TypicallyDecoratedCar.jpg|thumb|Decorated Undie 500 vehicle (there is a van behind the facade).]] [[File:Undie500Noah.jpg|thumb|2006 Undie 500 entry "Noah's Ark", winner best overall]]
The '''Undie 500''', originally named the '''Under 500''', was an annual student-run [[car rally]] between [[Christchurch]] and [[Dunedin]], New Zealand with multiple stops at drinking establishments along the way. The name comes from the original rule that a vehicle is purchased for less than [[New Zealand dollar|NZ$]]500, and optionally decorated.
The event has run since the early 1980s and is organised by the [[University of Canterbury Engineering Society Inc. (ENSOC)]]. The premise of the event is for student members of ENSOC to purchase and decorate a vehicle before rallying the cars to [[Dunedin]]. The vehicles are individually themed and occupants [[pub crawl]] over the entire day of driving. This event is characterised by the high level of work performed on the entrants' cars; transforming them from normal motor vehicles into something unique.
The event was originally to coincide with the weekend of the annual Canterbury University Engineers v Otago Surveyors rugby match. At this time and well into the 1990s it was known as the "Under 500". Somewhere along the way it has been transformed into the "Undie 500", presumably to establish a similar-sounding name to the more famous [[Indy 500]].
Since 2003, the number of vehicles was limited to 150. The event used to attract more than 1,000 participants and thousands of spectators. The event was widely reported, attracting national TV news coverage, newspaper, radio and has even featured in ''[[Ralph (magazine)|Ralph]]'' magazine. The [[New Zealand Police]] accompany the convoy throughout the trip to ensure both the safety of participants and other road users.
Since 2006, when others driving cars not associated with the event began traveling to Dunedin concurrently and rioting,<ref name="ODT_73741">{{cite web |url=http://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/73741/tradition-cars-rip-roaring-good-time |title=Tradition, cars, the rip-roaring good time |author=Porteous, Debbie |date=12 September 2009 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> the event has also received much negative publicity due to rioting students and others associated with the event. Some have been charged with offenses including offensive language and breaching the liquor ban the Dunedin City Council had placed.<ref name="rocky"/>
After the 2009 event, the head of the [[University of Canterbury Students' Association]] (UCSA) noted that they could not "exert authority on those hangers-on or those other students and young people that head to Dunedin to use this as an excuse for violence or anti-social behaviour.", and that it was no longer in the interest of students to be associated with those who were causing trouble after the event.<ref name="ODT_74432">{{cite web |url=http://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/74432/undie-over-dunedin |title=Undie over for Dunedin |date=17 September 2009 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> Consequently, the 2009 head of the UCSA predicted ENSOC could not run a further event to Dunedin in light of the trouble that would be caused by those non-students who would use it as an excuse for violence and other anti-social behaviour, but appeared not to rule out a similar event heading to a different destination.
Many in Dunedin see the event as having been sensationalised by the media, with one local noting the "local newspaper will start printing stories a week in advance, and will continue for a week after the event, even if it runs smoothly."<ref name="NZ_Herald_10610537">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10610537 |title=The Job Tour: Media blamed for Dunedin students' reputation |author1=Andrew Hughes |author2=Olivia Wix |lastauthoramp=yes |date=20 November 2009 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref>
==Rules== Cars were expected to meet the following requirements: * Have a current [[Warrant of Fitness]] and [[Vehicle registration]] * Be driven by a [[sobriety|sober]] driver
In previous years it was also a requirement to have a vehicle under the price of $500, hence the name UNDIE 500. However, due to rising prices and stricter regulations this rule was later overlooked.
==Prizes== Before embarking for Dunedin, cash prizes were awarded for outstanding entries including: * Best Car * Best Dressed Team * Best Mechanical Car * Best Structural Car * Best Engineered Car * Most [[Politically Incorrect]] Car * Best Overall
==Disorder==
===1994=== The winner of best dressed vehicle in 1994 was a 1964 HD Holden Special station wagon cleverly transformed into Thomas The Tank Engine. It featured in an article on the Under 500 in The Timaru Herald newspaper. That year there was a bad snow storm on The Kilmog hill, just north of Dunedin. The local police stopped many of the cars on their way up the hill due to the icy conditions. This vehicle was allowed through as it was explained to the officer, "This is a train, not a car".
===2006=== The 2006 event was marred by drunken rioting in the Castle St area of [[Dunedin]]; resulting in 30 arrests and a [[liquor ban]] subsequently imposed on the main student area over the events weekend.<ref name="NZ_Herald_10397227">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10397227 |title=Dunedin police face drunken, rioting students |date=21 August 2006 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> After the incident ENSOC worked with the various local authorities in [[Ashburton, New Zealand|Ashburton]], [[Timaru]], [[Oamaru]] and [[Dunedin]] to minimise any possible disruption caused to local residents, including paying the [[Dunedin City Council]] to tow away any abandoned vehicles.<ref>[http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/ED0708/S00066.htm Scoop: ENSOC Undie 500<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===2007=== [[File:Undie 500 fire, Grange St, Dunedin, NZ.jpg|thumb|right|Two members of the [[New Zealand Fire Service]] dousing an Undie 500 fire on Grange Street in 2007]] In 2007 the event saw further drunken rioting in which 69 people were arrested, on a night which one student involved described it as "a usual Dunedin Saturday night", while Dunedin emergency service workers said it was the city's worst trouble for many years.<ref name="TVNZ_1323121">{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/423466/1323121 |title=Undie 500 could be banned |date=27 August 2007 |work=[[Television New Zealand]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> Crowd estimates were 1,000 – 2,000 at the height of the riots. Couches, a mattress and at least two Undie 500 cars were torched on Castle, Dundas, Hyde, Grange, and Leith streets, and police and fire-fighters were pelted with bottles. 9 of the 24 University of Canterbury students arrested were officially registered on the Undie 500, along with 30 Dunedin students and 15 non-students.<ref name=history/> Subsequently, there have been calls for an end to the event, with the [[Mayor of Dunedin]] [[Peter Chin]] calling the event 'history'.<ref name=history>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/33517 |title=Undie 500 'history' – Mayor |date=27 August 2007 |publisher=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref>
In response to the rioting, police upgraded charges from disorderly behaviour to the more serious crime of [[rioting]] for 21 of the 69 arrested people, which could have resulted in up to 2 years in prison.<ref name="NZ_Herald_10460661">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/category/story.cfm?c_id=30&objectid=10460661 |title=Charges upgraded after Undie 500 riots |date=30 August 2007 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> These charges were later dropped by the police, with ten offenders pleading guilty and six pleading not guilty to lesser offences,<ref>{{cite news|title=Police drop Undie 500 rioting charges|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10480023|date=3 December 2007|work=NZ Herald|accessdate=6 May 2008}}</ref> resulting in at least one conviction for fifteen people.<ref name=ODT_500_please>{{cite web|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/18129/undie-500-convictions-please-police|title=Undie 500 convictions please police|author1=Porteous, Debbie |author2=Reid, Marian |lastauthoramp=yes |date=16 August 2008|work=Otago Daily Times|accessdate=16 August 2008}}</ref> Furthermore, [[University of Otago]] students involved in the rioting also risked being expelled from the university.<ref name="TVNZ_1324056">{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/413551/1324056 |title=Rampaging students face boot from uni |date=27 August 2007 |publisher=[[Television New Zealand]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> 31 people were charged at the Dunedin District Court, 22 being convicted (9 on two charges), and 5 receiving diversion. One charge of disorderly likely to cause violence was upheld on appeal to the High Court. The people convicted were forced to pay fines, reparations, donations and court costs exceeding $16,500 (up to $2,000 for some individuals), and received 250 hours community service, in addition to lawyers fees estimated at up to $1,000 to $5,000 each.<ref name=ODT_500_please/>
===2008=== Chin later said he expected the event would go ahead for 2008,<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20081016161106/http://www.aus.ac.nz/Publications/tertiaryupdate/2008/No%203.asp#6 AUS – The Association of University Staff of New Zealand<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> though he soon pulled out of meetings with ENSOC and emergency services.<ref name="underground">{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/286176 |title='Underground' Undie 500? |date=25 February 2008 |work=[[The Press]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> ENSOC had submitted a management plan with bonds and behavioural guarantees for participants,<ref name=underground/> and had planned for a concert for the Saturday night after the official event, which has been the scene of the rioting in recent years. Meetings had been held with concert promoters with the aim of organizing a large event with a budget of over $100,000.<ref>''[[Canta (magazine)|Canta]]'', Issue 3, 12 March 2008, pp. 18–19</ref> Without approval, ENSOC are refusing to condone the 'underground' Undie 500 that they expect to occur.<ref name=underground/>
In 2008 the official event was cancelled, but around 100 students from the University of Canterbury travelled to Dunedin in about 40 cars and vans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/thepress/4662004a24035.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120912094613/http://www.stuff.co.nz/thepress/4662004a24035.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 September 2012|title=Rerun for rally that led to riot|author1=Hartevelt, John |author2=Suisted, Narelle |lastauthoramp=yes |date=20 August 2008|publisher=The Press|accessdate=30 August 2008}} </ref><ref name="NZ_Herald_Around30">{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10528717|title=Around 30 students arrested after riot police move in|date=24 August 2008|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=30 August 2008}}</ref> More than 100 police were rostered on for the event, and had placed checkpoints on the outskirts of Rolleston and the entrance to Dunedin city. The media once again reported the event sparked violence, with police in full riot gear three times charging a group of around 500 students throwing rocks and bottles, before dispersing the crowd in the early hours of 24 August 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/19219/rogue-undie-descends-mayhem|title=Rogue Undie descends into mayhem|last=Porteous|first=Debbie|date=24 August 2008|work=Otago Daily Times|accessdate=30 August 2008}}</ref> While police Inspector Dave Campbell noted that the event was not a catalyst for the trouble, with most of those arrested from Otago University or non-students, he also said that to those persons "It's quite clear that it [the Undie 500] is seen as a magnet."<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_595411">{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/595411 |title=Otago students to blame for Undie mayhem – police |date=24 August 2008 |publisher=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> Around 30 arrests were made, in addition to 3 University of Canterbury and 2 University of Otago students from the previous night.<ref name="NZ_Herald_Around30"/>
===2009=== [[Image:Undie500-Man-Arrested-2009.jpg|thumb|right|A man is arrested during riots after the 2009 Undie 500]] An official ENSOC charity event ran in 2009, after Dunedin Mayor Peter Chin refused to negotiate with the University of Canterbury Students Association and ENSOC to organise events after the main Undie rally to minimise disorder afterwards. About 600 students from Canterbury participated,<ref name="3_News_120735">{{cite web |url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Undie-500-kicks-off-under-watchful-eye-of-police-/tabid/368/articleID/120735/cat/64/Default.aspx |title=Undie 500 kicks off, under watchful eye of police – Video |work=[[3 News]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> bringing more than 1000 cans of food for Dunedin food banks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/on-campus/university-otago/73905/undie-500-delivers-foodbanks|title=Undie 500 delivers for foodbanks|last=Fox|first=Rebecca |date=14 September 2009|work=Otago Daily Times|accessdate=14 September 2009}}</ref> The "Undie Charity Drive" has been criticised by Chin as "no matter how it is dressed up it is just a pub crawl." While the rally featured decorated cars, costumes and alcohol, new measures such as a good behaviour bond were introduced to address previous concerns. These measures, could, however, only be used to control behaviour by Canterbury University students, not Otago University students or the unemployed.
[[Oamaru]], through which the event passes, was "proactive" (according to their community constable), and organised to deal with any increased littering or other anti-social behaviour as a result of the event.<ref name="ODT_73395">{{cite web |url=http://www.odt.co.nz/the-regions/north-otago/73395/proactive-stance-over-rally |title=Proactive stance over rally |author=Bruce, David |date=10 September 2009 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> The town experienced no major problems, with only two arrests.<ref name="ODT_74025">{{cite web |url=http://www.odt.co.nz/the-regions/north-otago/74025/offences-spur-police-warning |title=Offences spur police warning |author=Bruce, David |date=15 September 2009 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref>
The event ran successfully, with partying afterwards becoming chaotic as police in riot gear moved in to be pelted with bottles, bricks and bicycle parts.<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_2857951">{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/2857951/Undie-500-chaos-in-Dunedin-again |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130223072710/http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/2857951/Undie-500-chaos-in-Dunedin-again |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 February 2013 |title=MP, mayor want Undie 500 out of Dunedin |date=12 September 2009 |publisher=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=12 September 2011 }}</ref> Over two nights 80 arrests were made – around 80% University of Otago students, 10% University of Canterbury students, and 10% not students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/on-campus/university-otago/73909/mayor-riled-after-80-arrests|title=Mayor riled after 80 arrests|last=Morris|first=Chris |date=14 September 2009|work=Otago Daily Times|accessdate=14 September 2009}}</ref> In response to the disorder, Chin blamed Christchurch students.<ref name="NZ_Herald_10596949">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10596949 |title=Cities blame each other for undies riots |author=Nash, Kieran |date=13 September 2009 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> Police charged 67 people with a range of offences including breaching the temporary liquor ban, disorderly behaviour, obstruction and burning couches.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.campuscop.co.nz/fires.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926082012/http://www.campuscop.co.nz/fires.html |archivedate=26 September 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.police.govt.nz/news/release/20988.html|title=Charges Laid in Relation to Weekend Disorder in Dunedin|date=14 September 2009 |publisher=New Zealand Police|accessdate=14 September 2009}}</ref> Prime Minister [[John Key]] described the incident as "madness" and pointed out some students would consequently graduate with criminal convictions.<ref name="NZ_Herald_10597249">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10597249 |title=Student riots lead to almost 70 arrests |date=14 September 2009 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref>
In the aftermath, [[Otago University Students' Association|OUSA]] president Edwin Darlow pointed out that as there was no way to stop the event,<ref name="3_News_120889">{{cite web |url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Students-criticise-council-response-to-Undie-500/tabid/423/articleID/120889/cat/64/Default.aspx |title=Students criticise council response to Undie 500 |date=13 September 2009 |work=[[3 News]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> the council should consider alternative events over the weekend to reduce disorder after it finishes,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/crime/2860202/Police-charge-67-after-Undie-500-madness |title=Police charge 67 after Undie 500 'madness' |author=Fitzsimons, Tom |date=14 September 2009 |publisher=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> though Chin has consistently refused to consider options ENSOC has proposed.<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_588297">{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/588297 |title=Rerun for rally that led to riot |date=19 August 2008 |work=[[The Press]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> Bystanders complained of being pepper sprayed by police in their own doorways.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/crime/2860202/Mayor-calls-for-Undie-500-ban |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130223004100/http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/crime/2860202/Mayor-calls-for-Undie-500-ban |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 February 2013 |title=Police charge 67 after Undie 500 'madness' |author=Fitzsimons, Tom |date=14 September 2009 |publisher=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=12 September 2011 }}</ref> An 18-year-old [[Telford Rural Polytechnic]] student who travelled from [[Balclutha, New Zealand|Balclutha]], specifically to be part of the "Undie 500 weekend", fell onto a burning couch while trying to jump over it. He was taken to [[Dunedin Public Hospital]] suffering burns, and required surgery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/74182/couch-leap-039stupid039-burnt-student-says|title=Couch leap 'stupid', burnt student says|last=McNeilly|first=Hamish|date=16 September 2009|work=Otago Daily Times|accessdate=16 September 2009}}</ref>
In response to the event police minister [[Judith Collins]] said on [[3 News]] the rioters were "spoilt little rich kids, who think that they are going to be the future leaders of our country, and frankly if they are, God help us".<ref>{{cite web | author=3 News | title=Undie 500 Rolls out of Dunedin, leaving carnage behind | url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Undie-500-rolls-out-of-Dunedin-leaving-carnage-behind/tabid/303/articleID/120873/cat/772/Default.aspx | publisher=3 News | date=13 September 2009 | accessdate=14 September 2009}}</ref>
Charges against two of those arrested were withdrawn because police lacked valid evidence.<ref name="rocky">{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/2877296/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130222234305/http://www.stuff.co.nz/2877296/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 February 2013 |title=Rocky road ahead for Undie 500 |author=Todd, Rebecca |date=18 September 2009 |publisher=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |accessdate=12 September 2011 }}</ref> On 14 September, the first three of those arrested appeared in court; one a Dunedin student, and two unemployed and employed persons respectively from Dunedin.<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_2863866">{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/southland-times/news/court/2863866/First-Undie-500-group-in-court-tomorrow |title=First Undie 500 group in court tomorrow |date=14 September 2009 |work=[[The Southland Times]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> The day after, a mill-hand and a process worker were convicted of breaching the liquor ban.<ref name="ODT_74123">{{cite web |url=http://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/74123/teen-remanded-over-undie-unrest |title=Teen remanded over Undie unrest |date=15 September 2009 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> Of those facing charges, 43 are tertiary students. The largest group was of 27 Otago University students, followed by 18 who are not tertiary students, six of whom were unemployed.<ref name="rocky"/> On the 18th, one Otago student was convicted of theft for grabbing a police officers hat, valued at $80, for which he would later apologise to the officer. He was fined $500 with court costs of $130. Also convicted were two unemployed men and a shearer.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10598492 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20120906102214/http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10598492 | archive-date=6 September 2012 | deadurl=yes}} </ref>
The harshest penalty imposed has been on a 41-year-old unemployed Dunedin man for breaching the City Council liquor ban. Eight people have had charges against them dropped for lack of evidence against them, and two discharged without conviction.<ref name="ODT_80941">{{cite web |url=http://www.odt.co.nz/on-campus/university-otago/80941/otago-university-silent-undie-500-discipline |title=Otago University silent on Undie 500 discipline |author=Porteous, Debbie |date=6 November 2009 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref> One Dunedin student was suspended from the University for swearing at Dunedin University security staff, outside the University property, outside his flat.<ref name="TVNZ_3115037">{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/otago-student-banned-swearing-3115037 |title=Otago student banned for swearing |date=5 November 2009 |work=[[Television New Zealand]] |accessdate=12 September 2011}}</ref>
===2010=== In the year 2010 the Undie 500 Charity Drive was denied a liquor licence for an event that included a concert in Seddon. This was a blow to the event as it eventually led to the charity drive being cancelled in 2010.<ref>http://www.ensoc.info/wp-content/uploads/2010/09/ENSOC-EMAIL-18.pdf{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The committee ended up spending funds set asides on helping relief efforts for the Canterbury earthquake.
===2011=== After several meetings between event organisers [[ENSOC]], the Dunedin police, Christchurch and the Dunedin city council the event was organised as a pub crawl that left from the university and returned to Christchurch. The event was kept off Facebook and the ENSOC website in an effort to keep it out of the media's attention, removing the negative publicity that is normally associated with the event.
The event consisted of leaving from the university arts car park, as in previous years, then heading out to the first pub in Yarldhurst. Both the participants and police were well behaved. Following that the event continued further out on to the Canterbury plains, finally ending back at a pub in Templeton, just out of Christchurch.
===2017=== The name Undie 500 was revitalised in 2017 by former University of Otago student [[Ryan Hellyer]], who created the new annual Undie 500 event<ref>{{cite news| url=https://undiecar.com/event/undie-500/ | title=Undie 500 2017 | date=December 2017 | deadurl=no}} </ref> as a special event for the [[Undiecar Championship]], a sim racing series run on the iRacing platform. The most recent event in 2018 attracted 33 competitors<ref>{{cite news| url=https://undiecar.com/event/undie-500-2/ | title=Undie 500 2018 | date=October 2018 | deadurl=no}} </ref>.
